Gastronomic business is permitted from 6a.m. to 11p.m. People who live in the same household or a maximum of four adults plus their underage children may sit at one table. There must be a distance of 1 meter to other groups of visitors. As an alternative to the 1 meter distance rule, suitable protective measures for spatial separation are also permitted. The guests are led to the table by the staff which must wear face masks. Also museums, exhibitions, libraries and archives can be visited in accordance with hygiene and distance rules. Dance schools can be visited with a person who lives in the same household, the partner or in individual lessons. Outdoor sport facilities can be used by persons who live in the same household and keep a distance of at least 2 meters. Top athletes are also allowed to train indoors

Return of compulsory school-age pupils includes around 700000 pupils at elementary schools, lower AHS schools, new middle schools (NMS), special schools as well as all German remedial classes. Measure_L4: Conditional entry of citizens of Germany and Switzerland

The same applies to owners of agricultural, hunting or forest land. People who have to look after animals are also allowed to enter.

Measure_L4: Operation of small liner trades and taxi boats
Comment: Liner trade and boat taxis can operate according to the saftey guidlines (people who do not live in the same household must wear mouth and nose protection and keep a distance of at least one meter from each other). Cabin ships and excursion ships are not allowed to start operations until May 28th

Comment: Re-opening of tourist accommodations, outdoor pool facilities, carnival businesses and further culture areas under the restriction of social distancing and the mandatory use of face masks

Comment: Means of transport that are not considered to be mass transport (max. 10 persons) can operate under the rules of carpooling (people who do not live in the same household must wear mouth and nose protection and keep a distance of at least one meter from each other). The same applies to taxis, taxi-like businesses, traveling buses, airplanes and cableway  businesses

When confronted with criticism from some of those who have been given fines, that the police are enforcing the rules way too strict, he says: “When we have a prohibition, it must be enforced.” The prohibition on stopping at Islands Brygge is in effect until the 1st of May at 23.59. 34 people have been charged for having violated the ban on gathering more than 10 people in public on Theklavej in the Northwest quarter in Copenhagen. The 34 were sitting in a private clubroom without an acknowledgeable purpose. They have all received 2.500 kroner in fine, a total of 85.000 kroner.

In Chimborazo, the Riobamba Autonomous Decentralized Government (GAD) donated 5,000 rapid tests for COVID-19 detection to the Ministry of Public Health, in order to carry out more tests on the population. The Vice Minister of Comprehensive Care of the Ministry of Public Health (MSP), Ernesto Carrasco, reported on April 5 that the National Government continues to strengthen protection measures for personnel working in the health sector. And he stressed that the care system does not collapse, since it is dynamic and it works in coordination between the public and private network to provide the assistance that the country requires. The authority appreciated the donation of implements by the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) and reported that 10,000 gloves and 5,000 surgical suits will be delivered to all hospitals in the public network. In addition, it indicated that 1,100 kimono suits arrived to be distributed in the entities for COVID-19. Although there is a daily demand for protection implements -some of these are not reusable-, she stressed that biosa<2FEMININE> tools are being renewed so that, every day, staff have what it takes to carry out their work.
Mandatory use of masks to circulate in public spaces.

This Monday, April 6, the Vice Minister of Governance and Surveillance of the Ministry of Public Health (MSP), Julio López, reiterated that PCR diagnostic tests that determine whether or not a person is infected with COVID-19 are being carried out normally, throughout the national territory. In this regard, he announced that during the week rapid tests will be distributed in all provinces. These will contribute to an early diagnosis of the disease
Saturday and Sunday any circulation in car is forbidden (except emergency cases and key workers)

This Tuesday, April 7, the Vice Minister of Governance and Surveillance of the Ministry of Public Health (MSP), Julio López, reported that, in the framework of the expansion of the diagnostic capacity for the detection of COVID-19 that is carried out in the country, several higher education institutions will join. “ We have two qualified universities and others are being considered in order to incorporate them. They are: the San Francisco de Quito and the Catholic (of Quito), ”he said. He reiterated that in addition to this, the National Institute for Public Health Research (Inspi) incorporated a molecular testing sequencer to increase daily service. Likewise, the laboratories of public specialty hospitals are operating and cooperation agreements have been coordinated with private laboratories, which are already carrying out the tests.

Measure_L2: Measures to ensure security of supply
Comment: The work of the National Government in the provinces is standing firm to contain the spread of the COVID-19 virus. Governments and farmers in different areas of the country work to establish and implement various mechanisms that ensure food supplies and that allow the population to access products at fair prices.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Comment: Implementation of a "regional traffic light" on the restrictions imposed by COVID-19 in order to gradually reactivate the economy and consolidate a monitoring system for those infected by geolocation (starts with red for the whole country)

Measure_L3: Prohibition of export of protective personal equipment
Comment: There is an export restriction on 24 products that are necessary for the protection and care of health facilities and personnel.

Measure_L2: Increase in medical supplies and equipment
Measure_L3: Ban on exportation of medical equipment and drugs
Comment: There is an export restriction on 24 products that are necessary for the protection and care of health facilities and personnel.

Measure_L2: Increase in medical supplies and equipment
Comment: temporarily eliminated the tariff for the import of health equipment

The Government Minister, María Paula Romo, informed the public of several resolutions adopted this April 16 by the National Committee for Emergency Operations (COE). Among them, the opening of 4,000 additional points of non-financial correspondents was authorized to collect the Family Protection Bond throughout the country. Thus, from today, the beneficiaries will be able to withdraw it in the places that provide the service of Mi Vecino (Banco Pichincha) and Banco del Barrio (Banco de Guayaquil). This measure seeks to prevent crowds and encourages people to withdraw money in the places closest to their sectors of residence. Likewise, he announced that the retirement payments of the Ecuadorian Social Security Institute (IESS) will be through a scheduling mechanism to avoid the massive influx of people in financial institutions. In this context, he recalled that the certificates that expired until March 16 - the start date of the State of Exception - will be valid for three more months, so that there is no impediment in the collection of the different assistances. And in the case of loss of the document, the procedure can be carried out by presenting the identity and civil status certificate, obtained on the Civil Registry website.

Measure_L2: The government provide assistance to vulnerable populations
Comment: Parallel to this work, the governorates and the Decentralized Autonomous Governments (GAD) continue with the delivery of aid to families with a high degree of vulnerability. For example, the Sucumbíos Prefecture and the Provincial COE delivered 700 food kits in the parishes of Jambelí, Seville, Santa Cecilia, Rosa Florida, El Eno and Nueva Troncal. While in Santa Elena, 140 kits were delivered to beneficiaries of the Rio Verde and El Azúcar districts.

Measure_L4: Resume production and market of office supplies and stationery (home delivery only)
Comment: However, starting Monday, April 20, companies that produce or market office supplies and stationery will operate, since there is a wide need for these supplies. This service will be provided at home, under the same regime that applies to restaurants. That is: under orders by phone or through mobile applications, with electronic invoicing and product delivery in compliance with strict sanitary regulations.

However, starting Monday, April 20, (...) also, according to the official announced, the workers of certain projects in the construction sector will resume work, under the respective security protocols. They will work in shifts and with constant monitoring of their health to detect early any possible condition or spread of COVID-9. The reactivation of this sector will serve for the authorities to evaluate a possible opening for other productive activities. "It does not mean that everyone in the sector can resume their activities, " said Romo.
At another point, the Minister of Government referred to the reopening of the Ambato Wholesale Market that took place today, April 24.

Measure_L3: To support law enforcement/sanction in case of no compliance
Comment: Furthermore, outside markets or small businesses, an agglomeration of people who do not wear masks and do not keep the suggested distance (one meter) between them has been detected. In these cases, the authorities sanctioned the offenders during operations carried out by officials from the police stations (national and municipal), Political Headquarters and the Sanitary Regulation and Control Agency.

Measure_L2: The government provide assistance to vulnerable populations
Comment: The morning of this April 30, the President of the Republic, Lenín Moreno Garcés, announced the delivery of solidarity baskets with perishable and non-perishable food to more than eight million Ecuadorians throughout the national territory. The products will be distributed through the support of tax schools, 180,000 neighborhood stores and the company Cervecería Nacional. Under the leadership of Vice President Otto Sonnenholzner and Cabinet Secretary Juan Sebastián Roldán, the rations will be delivered for two months to the homes of the most needy: people with disabilities, catastrophic illnesses and children in vulnerable situations. In this regard, the Cabinet secretary highlighted the lines of action of this initiative: the first, the delivery of school breakfast rations. the second, the distribution of the baskets through stores. the third, through the campaign Give a hand, without shaking hands , which is carried out thanks to the support of private companies and local governments. and the fourth, through georeferencing, to reach those with disabilities and the elderly. "More than 140,000 people will receive food at the door of their home," he said.

Measure_L4: Resume construction work related to hospital infrastucture
Comment: The Minister of Government, María Paula Romo, reported that the National Committee for Emergency Operations (COE) decided that all works related to hospital infrastructure restart their work as a priority, next week. The main objective: to increase the capacity of the health system. The Secretary of State explained that this decision was made in view of the fact that there are several buildings of public hospitals in the country that have an advance of 90% to 95%. For this reason, it is essential that its construction be completed

Starting Monday, May 4, Ecuador will go from social isolation to distancing, as announced by the Minister of Government, María Paula Romo. In the next few hours, the President of the Republic, Lenín Moreno, will explain the guidelines and scope of the new stage that will take place after the citizens comply with the mandatory quarantine period in the face of the health emergency by COVID-19.

Measure_L3: Partial lift of the curfew for certain workers
Comment: Although they have been working actively since the beginning of the health emergency, the home delivery of food or prepared food, better known as 'delivery', will increase its hours from Monday, May 4 in Ecuador. From now on, the hours are extended from 07:00 to 22:00, despite the curfew hours, which are maintained throughout Ecuador (14:00 to 05:00).
as of Monday, May 4, (…) for the taxi service (depending on the day they can circulate according to their license plate) the hours will be extended until 22:00.

Measure_L4: Reactivate sending of parcels between provinces
Comment: The sending of parcels between provinces will be reactivated and all the aforementioned will govern, even in the municipalities with red traffic lights.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Comment: At another point, Romo referred to the power that local authorities will have to define the traffic lights of their cantons. In this regard, he stressed that the powers of the Decentralized Autonomous Governments (GAD) remain the same and have to do mainly with: control of public space, regulations in markets and urban transport, cleaning and disinfection of cities. Meanwhile, the National Government has powers to manage the health emergency, the health system, public order, detentions, curfew, etc.

Measure_L2: The government provide assistance to vulnerable populations
Comment: In El Oro, temporary shelters are being set up for people on the street. These shelters, in the coming days, will gradually receive 1,000 beds and other supplies from the National Risk and Emergency Management Service. The activity is led by the government, in coordination with the municipal decentralized autonomous governments (GAD).

Measure_L4: New isolation structure for non-severe cases
Comment: In Esmeraldas, the local authorities decided to implement shelters in several cantons so that people infected with the virus comply with their isolation period. To achieve this goal, the mayors will provide the respective spaces.

Comment: The vice minister said that health professionals are joining together to provide help to all citizens. Thus, in the province of Pichincha, 150 experts have been hired and, in Guayas, the personnel is being redistributed and it is expected to have a task force of 250 doctors. In addition, he mentioned that the rural doctors have moved to Guayaquil to provide their service and that of the 700 vacancies planned for this coastal province alone, they hired 100 that have been distributed in the Guasmo Sur and Monte Sinaí hospitals.

Measure_L2: The government provide assistance to vulnerable populations
Comment: The contributions of different public and private entities, as well as individuals have been delivered to the governorates, from where they are distributed to families in a state of vulnerability under the protocols established by the National Government, to prevent the spread of COVID-19. In Imbabura the six chiefs and the 36 political lieutenants have channeled the aid delivered to the province. It began with the donation of 6,000 kits with essential products from the Ministry of Economic and Social Inclusion (MIES). This week it will be sent to the rural sector. In the same way, the valuable contribution was received from the private companies La Favorita and the Sugar Mill of the North, which benefited 2,500 families.

In Imbabura, USD 140,000 was delivered to the San Vicente de Paúl Hospital in Ibarra so that arrangements can be made in the tomography and in an elevator exclusively used for stretchers of patients with COVID-19. Likewise, the Imbabura Prefecture allocated USD 320,000 for the repowering of said health home (the main one in the capital of the province), the Asdrúbal de la Torre Hospital (Cotacachi) and the San Luis de Otavalo. In addition, thanks to a private contribution of USD 20,000, new protective equipment was purchased for medical personnel.

In Morona Santiago, the Government manages the adaptation of isolation centers for patients infected with the virus in the towns of Sucúa and Macas. These spaces will be equipped with beds and furniture, thanks to the contribution of their respective municipalities.

Measure_L2: Measures to ensure security of supply
Comment: In Orellana, Despite the fact that much of the province's work is focused on stopping the spread of the virus, it continues to meet the new requirements of the population. Regarding the suspension of the supply of drinking water in several communities due to the rupture of the pipes due to landslides, the government coordinates the supply of vital liquid by river and land. It is done twice a week and for this it has the support of Petroamazonas and the OCP company, which provide equipment such as a water pump and also collaborate with the transfer of spare parts, should they be needed.

The National Government continues with the delivery of economic resources for the health houses of the different provinces of the country, so that they have all the necessary implements to face the COVID-19 and better serve the population. This while the governments channel aid from public and private institutions for the neediest families in their localities. In Orellana, government authorities handed over more than USD 453,000 to health care centers in the province. Of this amount, USD 350,000 went to the General Hospital of Francisco de Orellana, the main health facility in the area. The resources will be for the acquisition of medical protection equipment and medicines.

For its part, the National Police, through the United Nations Police (UNPOL) group, in the company of health officials, deliver medicine to patients with chronic diseases, in order to prevent them from leaving their homes.

Measure_L4: Mobile clinical unit for pregnant women and vaccination

In this unit medical care is provided only to pregnant women and also, there is a vaccination service. Meanwhile, the emergency area (non-respiratory symptoms) was relocated to the health center so that patients with coronavirus are exclusively cared for.

For taxpayers who are dedicated to the generation, transmission, distribution and commercialization of electric energy, as well as the taxpayers dedicated to subscription of television services, residential and commercial internet services, fixed and mobile telephony, the CIT payment is extended without fees or interest provided that they request an instalment payment option in which the first instalment will start on May 31st. There is no extension for the presentation of the tax return. The payment of the advance income tax for the months of March, April and May is extended without fees or interest for the taxpayers who are dedicated to subscription of television services, residential and commercial internet services, fixed and mobile telephony provided that they request instalment payment option.

"The government has decided to temporarily reintroduce border control...Of course, all residents of Estonia and their close relatives can still return to the country. Estonia's borders closed to all except: citizens of Estonia, permanent residents, their relatives, and transport workers carrying out freight transport.

The Defence League may be involved in this task for up to 30 days."

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public

Up to two people are allowed to be together in public space. This restriction does not apply to families living and moving around together, and to people performing public duties. The space requirement between people will come into effect tomorrow, March 25.

Comment: Government Office signed an agreement with an Estonian business guaranteeing 50,000 FFP3 respirators a week for half a year from mid-April. The factory is making preparations to double production to produce up to 100,000 masks a week for the country.

Comment: 250 million euros will be directed to a measure through the Estonian Unemployment Insurance Fund, which will help maintain the income of employees during the emergency.

Exhibitions in open-air museums and outside premises of museums will also be opened for visitors. Museums and exhibition areas may open their indoor premises if they only allow visitors in groups of up to 10 people. Exceptions apply to families. Visitors must follow the 2 + 2 rule and have access to disinfectants. all surfaces that are frequently touched by visitors must be wet-cleaned.

Catering facilities in shopping centres that until now were only allowed to sell takeout can start serving food on the spot.
The restriction on serving food on the spot after 10 p.m. remains in force to prevent evening gatherings in restaurants, cafés, and bars.
Casinos, slot machine halls, entertainment and amusement facilities (like poolrooms and bowling alleys), etc. will remain closed.
Sports facilities, children’s playrooms will remain closed.
The restriction on organising public gatherings, film screenings, nightclub events, theatre performances, concerts, and conferences will also remain in force in shopping centres as well as elsewhere.

The Government of the Republic decided that the restrictions for border crossings between Estonia and Finland will be eased as of the second half of next week, and that free movement of Estonian, Latvian and Lithuanian residents and people legally residing in these countries will resume.

Measure_L4: Lift mandatory quarantine for commuters and students
Comment: In addition to people working in Finland, the requirement for self-isolation after the border crossing will be lifted for people who come from Finland to Estonia to work or to study. People coming to Estonia for urgent family reasons, such as to see a close relative, or for a wedding or a funeral, will not have to observe the self-isolation requirement.

Measure_L1: Case identification, contact tracing and related measures
Comment: Additional requirements are applied on ships and ports: from May 14 to 9, voluntary testing will be carried out for coronavirus causing COVID-19 on board of ships travelling between Finland and Estonia. The aim of testing is to reduce the possible spread of the virus to Estonia.

Measure_L2: Increase in medical supplies and equipment
Measure_L3: Increase domestic production of medical equipment
Comment: The Government decided today to extend the duties of Jaak Aab as the central procurer of personal protective equipment until 31 December 2020.

As of 15 May, regular educational activities may be continued in schools under special conditions. This applies for schools of general education, vocational education, higher education, further education, hobby and recreational activity schools, and open youth centres. During the time when emergency restrictions are being eased, educational activities may be organised on school premises for groups of up to 10 people. The restriction does not apply to exams, state examinations, and vocational examinations if they are organised in large rooms, such as in assembly halls, gyms, or larger auditoriums. Public utilities must be constantly disinfected and school rooms frequently ventilated if educational activities are resumed. Students, practitioners, and organisers of educational activities must do everything in their power to prevent the COVID-19 infection from spreading. Protective masks are not mandatory. Practitioners of recreational activities, teachers, academic employees who organise higher education, and students are still strongly advised to wear masks and use other personal protective equipment if they are in a risk group.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Government supports the obtention of unemployment benefits
Comment: Extend the remuneration compensation until the end of June and to narrow the criteria of the measure. “The remuneration compensation measure designed to mitigate the effects of the crisis, from which employers have been able to apply for support to pay workers since March, has helped to maintain jobs and people’s incomes and has improved the situation of companies in difficulty in the current crisis. We must make efforts to help our working people and businesses survive the difficult times and contribute to economic recovery,” said Prime Minister Jüri Ratas. “Therefore, we considered it important to continue with the measure until the end of June so that the necessary assistance would still continue at the beginning of the summer after the emergency situation ended,” the Prime Minister added. The Minister of Social Affairs Tanel Kiik said he considered it important to support workers and employers and to avoid large-scale redundancies, as recruitment later is more complex and training more costly. “We have to take into account that there may be additional applicants, and we want the possibility of applying for compensation to primarily be available for employers whose situation is the most difficult. To extend the measure, the Government agreed to allocate up to EUR 36 million of funds to the Unemployment Insurance Fund from the reserve of the Government of the Republic,” said Kiik.

Measure_L1: Case identification, contact tracing and related measures
Measure_L4: Those known to have been in contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case are placed in quarantine.
Comment: The government has renewed the validity of the order regulating quarantine.  During a telecommunications session, the government renewed the quarantine requirements applicable to people diagnosed with COVID-19 and people living with them or permanently staying in the same place of residence, with a new term of 30 September 2020. As previously, people diagnosed with COVID-19 are forbidden from leaving their place of residence or permanent place of stay until their illness has ended, except at the order of a healthcare worker or police officer or in an emergency endangering the person’s life or health.

Measure_L1: Case identification, contact tracing and related measures

During a telecommunications session, the government renewed the quarantine requirements applicable to people diagnosed with COVID-19 and people living with them or permanently staying in the same place of residence, with a new term of 30 September 2020. As previously, people diagnosed with COVID-19 are forbidden from leaving their place of residence or permanent place of stay until their illness has ended, except at the order of a healthcare worker or police officer or in an emergency endangering the person’s life or health.

Considering the decrease in the spread of the coronavirus, the government decided today to relax the 2+2 rule requirement. Dispersion requirements will replace the 2+2 rule in all public spaces, such as stores, service points and public-use spaces at shopping centres, as well as at casinos and slot machine locations. In place of the 2+2 rule, dispersion must also be ensured at public events, public meetings and religious services.
As of 1 July, the government also decided to reopen nightclubs, hookah bars and adult entertainment clubs.

As of July 1, movies, performances, concerts, conferences, fairs, festivals, and other public events are allowed, including indoor and outdoor sports competitions without spectators, if the 2+2 rule is observed, the indoor premises are filled to no more than 50 per cent of capacity. In total, no more than 500 people can participate in any indoor event, even if the 50 capacity of the space exceeds that amount.

Measure_L3: Lift ban on conferences, meetings, trade fairs

In total, no more than 500 people can participate in any indoor event, even if the 50 capacity of the space exceeds that amount.

Measure_L3: Lift ban on outdoor sport events
Comment: From 1 July, sports competitions can be held with spectators, provided that the 2 + 2 rule is observed, the organisers comply with the 50 per cent capacity requirement, and no more than 500 persons take part of the event.
From July 1 the number of participants in the outdoor event may be up to 1000 persons.

The government approved the decision requiring nursing home staff and visitors to wear protective masks. The requirement to wear masks shall enter into force on Monday, 14 September.

Tallinn, Stenbock House, 17 September 2020 – the government approved a nationwide restriction on the sale of alcohol, which will take effect on the night of 24/25 September at 12 a.m. Late-night alcohol sales will be forbidden from 12 a.m. to 10 a.m. in all points of sale where alcohol is sold for consumption on the spot, for example, bars, nightclubs, restaurants, theatre buffets, and hotels.

From 29 September, up to 750 people will be allowed to attend indoor public meetings, events, and sports competitions instead of the current 1,500. Event organisers must follow the 50% occupancy requirement and ensure that the participants comply with the distancing requirements, as well as ensure the availability of disinfectants and compliance with the disinfection requirements.

Comment: "As a general guideline, persons over 70 years of age must refrain from contact with other persons to the extent possible (quarantine-like conditions), with the exception of members of parliament, the state leadership and elected officials in local government."

Measure_L3: Mobilization of domestic resources for health
Measure_L4: Healthcare professionals can be obliged to work if necessary
Comment: "Arrangements will be made to oblige trained professionals in healthcare and social welfare and internal security, in particular, to perform work as necessary."

Measure_L4: Extension of the maximum amount of working hours allowed for critical workers
Comment: "In the case of critical personnel, exceptions will be made to the provisions of the Working Hours Act and the Annual Holidays Act in both the private and public sector."

Measure_L3: Postponement of non-essential care and non-urgent operations in hospitals
Comment: "non-urgent activities will be reduced. The capacity of the private sector will be mobilised for public use as necessary. "
"The movement of people may be restricted in order to prevent a serious danger to life and health."

"All national and municipal museums, theatres, the National Opera, cultural venues, libraries, mobile libraries, services for customers and researchers at the National Archives, hobby and leisure centres, swimming pools and other sports facilities, youth centres, clubs, organisations- meeting rooms, day care services for the elderly, rehabilitative work facilities and workshops will be closed."

"All national and municipal museums, theatres, the National Opera, cultural venues, libraries, mobile libraries, services for customers and researchers at the National Archives, hobby and leisure centres, swimming pools and other sports facilities, youth centres, clubs, organisations, meeting rooms, day care services for the elderly, rehabilitative work facilities and workshops will be closed."

"All national and municipal museums, theatres, the National Opera, cultural venues, libraries, mobile libraries, services for customers and researchers at the National Archives, hobby and leisure centres, swimming pools and other sports facilities, youth centres, clubs, organisations- meeting rooms, day care services for the elderly, rehabilitative work facilities and workshops will be closed." until 13th April

Measure_L3: Measures to limit contact to hospital patients
Comment: "Visitors will be banned from care institutions, health care units and hospitals, with the exception of asymptomatic family members of children and critically ill individuals, family members of those in hospice care and spouses or support persons in the maternity ward, who will be permitted to visit on a case-by-case basis."

Measure_L3: Measures to limit contact to long-term care facilities
Measure_L4: Close long-term care facilities for visitors
Comment: "Visits to housing services for the elderly and other at-risk groups will be prohibited."
" Finnish citizens and persons residing in Finland must not travel abroad. "
"Public gatherings are limited to no more than ten persons, and it is recommend to avoid spending unnecessary time in public places."

Measure_L4: Law to ease the passing of laws
Comment: Decree on implementing the Emergency Powers Act is issued.

Measure_L3: Complete closure of primary and secondary schools
Comment: Under Emergency Powers Act all schools are closed (except early education) until 1st April
Under Emergency Powers Act all schools are closed (except early education) until 1st April

Measure_L1: Case identification, contact tracing and related measures
Comment: "It has been possible to report laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases to the National Infectious Diseases Register since 19 March 2020."

"The Government has decided to begin restricting cross-border traffic at Finland-s borders starting on Thursday 19 March at midnight. Border-crossing points will be closed and border controls will be reintroduced... Freight and goods traffic will continue at all borders. "

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Measure_L4: Launching of a cooperative team with the governement, media and social media influencers to ensure official communication about COVD-19 is reaching all population groups.
Comment: "The Prime Minister-s Office has launched cooperation with the Finnish Media Pool (part of the National Emergency Supply Agency) and PING Helsinki. The purpose of the cooperation is to support social media influencers in sharing information on the coronavirus with their followers."
Government decided to extend until 13 May 2020 the duration of the previously imposed restrictions
The restrictions on early childhood education, teaching and education and training will be extended by one month until 13 May at different levels of education.

Measure_L3: Complete closure of primary and secondary schools
Comment: The restrictions on early childhood education, teaching and education and training will be extended by one month until 13 May at different levels of education.

Measure_L1: Case identification, contact tracing and related measures
Measure_L4: Test contact or at risk of contact persons
Comment: Government also decided to further increase sampling and testing in Finland to identify cases of coronavirus and to curb the epidemic.

Measure_L1: Case identification, contact tracing and related measures
Comment: Healthcare and social welfare personnel must always be tested if there is even the slightest suspicion of illness.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Economic support to self-employees and free-lancers
Comment: The amount is EUR 2,000. This will be granted to cover the costs of running a business as a self-employed person without employees.

Measure_L2: The government provide assistance to vulnerable populations
Measure_L4: Home care for elderly and vulnerable children
Comment: The Ministry of Social Affairs and Health has given instructions to municipalities and joint municipal authorities on home care services during the coronavirus outbreak.

Measure_L2: Measures to ensure security of supply
Measure_L4: Consumable medical supplies and medical equipment and appliances
Comment: Government proposed an extension to the powers to restrict the sale of medicines, goods and services used in healthcare services, and it also broadened the use of these powers.

Measure_L3: Postponement of non-essential care and non-urgent operations in hospitals
Comment: Municipalities will continue to have the right to deviate from the time limits for providing non-urgent healthcare.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Comment: Temporary changes affecting companies and employees: The notice period for lay-offs is shortened: employers will be required to inform employees of the lay-off no later than five days before the lay-off begins. The duration of co-operation negotiations on lay-offs is shortened: the duration of the negotiations will be at least five days. Employees on a fixed-term contract may be laid off: employers will have the right to lay off an employee in a fixed-term employment relationship under the same conditions as an employee with an employment contract of unspecified duration. Termination of employment during trial period permitted: the employer may terminate the employment contract during the trial period for financial or production-related reasons. Employee re-employment obligation extended: the employer will be obligated, for a period of nine months, to re-employ those employees who were dismissed for financial or production-related reasons between 1 April and 30 June.

Measure_L3: State aid, taxation and social security
Measure_L4: Government supports the obtention of unemployment benefits
Comment: As of 1 April 2020, employees laid off will be entitled to unemployment benefit even if they are engaged in business activities or studies.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Comment: The purpose of the letter is to provide every citizen with information on coronavirus and ways to avoid getting the virus.

Measure_L4: Protocols to limit potential spread of Covid-19
Comment: Measures to prevent coronavirus infections in social welfare units providing 24-hour care: To prevent the spread of the coronavirus, residents must not be moved from a place of care or housing unit to another one during the epidemic, unless this is absolutely necessary to ensure their care. Care must always be provided if necessary on medical grounds.  The situation of the residents, especially new residents coming to the unit, must be followed very closely. Action must be taken immediately if any respiratory infection symptoms appear.

Measure_L4: Partial: remain open for take-away and/or delivery
Comment: All restaurants must be closed starting from Saturday 4 April 2020. The restrictions will remain in force until the end of May. The restrictions apply to all restaurant operations except for preparing food for take away and for delivery by food couriers.

Measure_L1: Case identification, contact tracing and related measures
Comment: As a main rule, all persons arriving in Finland are obliged, regardless of the reason for the border crossing, to follow the instructions of the Finnish health authorities and to remain under quarantine-like conditions for 14 days.

Measure_L3: Entry of workers under exceptional circumstances
Measure_L4: Seasonal workers in agriculture and forestry, and care and health personnel
Comment: On 25 March, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment appointed a group of authorities tasked with assessing the entry of workers under exceptional circumstances while Finland’s borders are mainly closed. Based on the authorities’ assessment, the Ministry has prepared a list of tasks that are essential from the point of view of security of supply or critical for the operations of the sector in question, and for which workers must be granted entry into the country.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Financial support to small and medium enterprises
Comment: As the most recent measure, on 14 April 2020 the Finnish Industry Investment Ltd Tesi will launch a new funding programme for medium-sized enterprises. The State allocates EUR 150 million for this programme.

In terms of countries and regions, Finland’s humanitarian assistance focuses on Africa and the Middle East, the allocations being EUR 19.4 million and EUR 14.4 million respectively. In addition, Finland supports Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Myanmar and Ukraine. Of individual crises, the most support, EUR 11 million, is allocated to the Syria crisis.
On 16 April, the Government issued a resolution confirming the amount of non-assigned voluntary funding that Finland will grant to the World Health Organization.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Comment: The aim of the new Finland Forward communication campaign to get people involved and give visibility to the great everyday work being done by various actors in society.

UNFPA and UN Women are among Finland's most important cooperation partners in the United Nations. In 2020, Finland supports UNFPA and UN Women by EUR 33 million and EUR 19 million respectively.Core funding is flexible support that organisations can direct to where it is most urgently needed.
This year, the authorities are encouraging people to spend vappu with their families at home, in their yards or nearby. The restrictions on gatherings of more than 10 people are still in force.

Even though Finland now faces emergency conditions, municipalities must continue to provide healthcare and social welfare services to ensure people’s safety and help them cope with everyday life. Municipalities must consider carefully whether to reduce basic public services. Active and sufficiently extensive operation of basic public services ensures that specialised medical care is able to focus on the treatment of patients requiring specialised medical care and that the health of any population group does not deteriorate unnecessarily. It is particularly important to ensure that those in the most vulnerable position have access to services.
A temporary amendment to the Aliens Act has been proposed to extend asylum seekers’ right to work.

An increase of EUR 10 million in the budget authority of the Academy of Finland is proposed for 2020. This is for the purpose of national COVID-19 vaccine and drug development research and research on the efficacy, safety and effectiveness of new coronavirus vaccines and drugs.

A total of EUR 6 million is proposed for expenditure on preparing, acquiring, introducing and maintaining a COVID-19 contact tracing application, and for discretionary government transfers for this, which will reinforce the ‘test, trace, isolate and treat’ approach of the Government’s hybrid strategy.

Measure_L3: State aid, taxation and social security
Measure_L4: Government supports the obtention of unemployment benefits
Comment: Due to the coronavirus crisis, the unemployment security expenditure for which the Employment Fund is responsible is increasing significantly. The Fund requires debt financing to cover the deficit and ensure its liquidity. To secure the availability of funding, it is proposed that a government guarantee be granted for a proposed maximum loan principal of EUR 800 million.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Support to hospitality and catering services
Comment: An appropriation of EUR 123 million is proposed for supporting food and beverage service businesses, to be used for compensating these businesses for the restrictions imposed on their activities, and to support the re-employment of their staff.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Facilitate loans for entrepreneurs and businesses
Comment: Government may grant a government guarantee of up to EUR 432 million on loans that are granted under the European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency (SURE).

Measure_L4: Covid-19 test-kits to most vulnerable countries
Comment: With support from Finland, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) will provide testing equipment needed in detecting the coronavirus to the IAEA member states that have requested support. The fight against the coronavirus pandemic requires extensive testing worldwide. Support from the IAEA is helping to increase testing capacity in the countries most in need. Finland is supporting this work with EUR 200,000 in voluntary funding.

Measure_L3: Guidelines for re-opening of educational institutions and leisure facilities
Measure_L4: Guidelines for re-opening of schools and daycare
Comment: Instructions that allow the return to early childhood education and contact teaching, taking care of safety and reducing the risk of COVID-19 infection.
Children in early childhood education and care and in primary and lower secondary school will return to contact teaching on Thursday 14 May.

As of 14 May 2020, the statutory restrictions on border traffic will be lifted in cross-border traffic across the Schengen internal borders by allowing employment or commission-related commuting and other essential traffic.

Measure_L1: Case identification, contact tracing and related measures
Comment: A person arriving in the country must restrict unnecessary close contacts and enter self-isolation for 14 days. Under self-isolation, the person is allowed to move between their workplace and place of residence and for other essential reasons.
Border control at internal borders will continue at land borders, ports and airports.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Comment: For the time being, recreational travel abroad is not recommended, and the travel advice issued by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs will be extended accordingly.

Measure_L3: Re-opening of public outdoor leisure facilities
Comment: Outdoor recreational facilities will be opened as of 14 May, subject to the restrictions on gatherings. Restrictions on gatherings are still necessary. Based on an epidemiological assessment, it will be possible to ease the restrictions on the number of persons from the current 10 to a maximum of 50 from 1 June until

Measure_L3: Measures to limit contact to long-term care facilities
Measure_L4: Close long-term care facilities for visitors
Comment: The restrictions concerning visits to healthcare and social welfare units will remain in force until further notice and the matter will be next reviewed by the end of June.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Measure_L4: Recommend the elderly to stay at home
Comment: Anyone aged over 70 years should continue to avoid physical contacts as far as possible.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Comment: The recommendation on working from home is continued until further notice.
Restrictions on the organisation of basic education in the arts will remain in force until 13 May, after which their premises will be opened correspondingly for contact teaching.

From 29 May, people can once again travel within Finland if they follow the safety guidelines related to coronavirus. In the current epidemic situation, the reopening of domestic tourism is not expected to significantly increase the spread of the epidemic, nor to cause overburdening of the healthcare system in tourist destinations. However, we must prepare for rapid regional changes and higher local risk levels.
It is important for tourists and tourism sector operators to be committed to complying with the measures in place to prevent COVID-19 infections.

Based on an epidemiological assessment, it will be possible to ease the restrictions on the number of persons from the current 10 to a maximum of 50 from 1 June until further notice. The 50-person limit applies not only to public gatherings (the recommendation-based guideline) but also to events organised by private and third-sector operators, to cultural, recreational, exercise and sports events and to religious events. As concerns indoor spaces and enclosed outdoor spaces, such as amusement parks, zoos, libraries and cinemas, safety will be ensured by limiting the number of visitors, ensuring safe distances and providing guidance on personal hygiene.
Large public events with more than 500 people are prohibited until 31 July 2020 in line with the Government's decision.

The following public indoor premises will be opened in a gradual and controlled manner as of 1 June: national and municipal museums, theatres, the National Opera, cultural venues, libraries, mobile libraries, services for customers and researchers at the National Archives, hobby and leisure centres, swimming pools and other sports facilities, youth centres, clubs, organisations’ meeting rooms, day care services for the elderly, rehabilitative work facilities and workshops.

The following public indoor premises will be opened in a gradual and controlled manner as of 1 June: national and municipal museums, theatres, the National Opera, cultural venues, libraries, mobile libraries, services for customers and researchers at the National Archives, hobby and leisure centres, swimming pools and other sports facilities, youth centres, clubs, organisations’ meeting rooms, day care services for the elderly, rehabilitative work facilities and workshops.

Measure_L4: Re-opening of gyms and fitness centers
Comment: The following public indoor premises will be opened in a gradual and controlled manner as of 1 June: national and municipal museums, theatres, the National Opera, cultural venues, libraries, mobile libraries, services for customers and researchers at the National Archives, hobby and leisure centres, swimming pools and other sports facilities, youth centres, clubs, organisations’ meeting rooms, day care services for the elderly, rehabilitative work facilities and workshops.

Measure_L3: Lift ban on outdoor sport events
Comment: Sports competitions and series can be resumed with special arrangements on 1 June.

The gradual opening of restaurants will begin on 1 June 2020, provided that this is supported by the effects of lifting the current restrictions and by the subsequent general epidemiological assessment. This requires legislative amendments that would enable imposition of restrictions on, for example, the number of customers and the alcohol serving hours.

The gradual opening of restaurants will begin on 1 June 2020, provided that this is supported by the effects of lifting the current restrictions and by the subsequent general epidemiological assessment. This requires legislative amendments that would enable imposition of restrictions on, for example, the number of customers and the alcohol serving hours.

Measure_L3: Guidelines for public events and public meetings
Comment: Public events and public meetings of more than 50 and a maximum of 500 persons in indoor and enclosed outdoor spaces can be organised under special arrangements. The Regional State Administrative Agencies require that such meetings and events be organised in accordance with the guidelines on the prevention of coronavirus infections issued by the Ministry of Education and Culture and the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare on 14 May 2020 (available in Finnish and Swedish).

Measure_L2: The government provide assistance to vulnerable populations
Measure_L3: Funds to expand support and services for vulnerable populations
Measure_L4: Funds to support the well-being of children and youth
Comment: Government has decided to introduce a wide-ranging package of measures worth approximately EUR 320 million for promoting the wellbeing of children and young people. The wellbeing package covers the administrative branches of three ministries: the Ministry of Education and Culture, the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health, and the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment.

Measure_L3: State aid, taxation and social security
Measure_L4: Government supports the obtention of unemployment benefits
Comment: An total increase of EUR 812 million is proposed for central government’s share of unemployment security.

Measure_L2: The government provide assistance to vulnerable populations
Measure_L3: Funds to expand support and services for vulnerable populations
Measure_L4: Funds to support the well-being of the elderly
Comment: The Government has decided to add a total of EUR 60 million to central government transfers to municipalities for services for older people.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Comment: The proposed package includes new financial support for business costs, amounting to a proposed EUR 300 million, to be introduced in the business sector. Business Finland’s authorisation to provide grants will be increased by EUR 180 million. These funds, allocated to measures to remedy disruptions in the production chain caused by the coronavirus epidemic, would increase the need for appropriations by EUR 120 million in 2020.

Measure_L3: State aid, taxation and social security
Comment: In order to support businesses, the Government proposes as a temporary measure that VAT payers could apply for a payment arrangement for the VAT already paid in January–March 2020. In addition, the interest rate of the adjusted payment arrangement would be reduced from 4 per cent to 3 per cent and the use of tax refunds for payment of instalments would be changed for a fixed period.

Measure_L3: To support law enforcement/sanction in case of no compliance
Comment: An increase of more than EUR 770 million is proposed in central government transfers to local government for the provision of basic public services. Of this, EUR 112 million would be allocated to support children, young people and families, and it would be distributed to local government under the system of central government transfers on the basis of the number of children. In addition, EUR 60 million would be allocated to ensuring the functioning of services for the elderly. EUR 50 million would be allocated to increase discretionary government transfers, and altogether EUR 550 million would be allocated to all municipalities, partly on a per capita basis and partly in proportion to local income tax in 2020.
A grant of EUR 200 million is proposed for hospital districts to offset the costs and potential financial deficits caused by COVID-19.
EUR 110 million is proposed to make provision for procuring a COVID-19 vaccine.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Comment: The Government proposes, due to the COVID-19 situation, additional funding of EUR 100 million for purchasing and developing public passenger transport services. The funding will be directed to support the safeguarding of the service level in public transport if the coronavirus situation persists.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Economic support to the media sector
Comment: The Government proposes to allocate EUR 5 million for the support of journalism in 2020. This will provide support to media facing financial difficulties due to the coronavirus situation.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Measure_L4: Promote the use of face masks
Comment: In its informal meeting on 3 June, the Government decided on the use of face masks. During the coronavirus epidemic, it is essential to maintain sufficient physical distance and observe good hand and respiratory hygiene to prevent infections. The Government will not issue a general recommendation on the use of face masks, but considers that masks can be used to protect other people in places and situations where it is not possible to avoid close contact.
On 11 June, the Government outlined its proposal that border control will continue partially at internal borders and external border traffic will continue to be restricted until 14 July 2020.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Comment: However, the Government still recommends avoiding unnecessary travel to other countries except for Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. Each and every one of us can help prevent the spread of the coronavirus epidemic by complying with travel recommendations and hygiene instructions.

Measure_L3: State aid, taxation and social security
Measure_L4: Government supports the obtention of unemployment benefits
Comment: The exempt amount of the unemployment benefit will be temporarily raised.The aim is provide financial support to help people find part-time work or other short-term work in agriculture and horticulture enterprises or elsewhere. Moreover, the raised exempt amount will also apply to income from self-employment and unemployed jobseekers who already receive adjusted unemployment benefit.

Government has determined that the COVID-19 epidemic can be managed using the regular powers of the authorities. In its plenary session today, the Government issued decrees repealing the use of powers under the Emergency Powers Act and announced that the current situation in the country no longer constitutes a state of emergency as referred to in section 3 of the Emergency Powers Act.

Measure_L2: The government provide assistance to vulnerable populations
Measure_L3: Funds to expand support and services for vulnerable populations
Comment: The purpose of the temporary compensation is to support the most vulnerable persons and families who have incurred extra costs as a result of the restrictions imposed by the coronavirus epidemic.The aid would cover persons who have received basic social assistance during the period of restrictions, if they continue to receive basic social assistance during the payment period in autumn 2020.

As of 22 June 2020, the decree will be amended so that food and beverage service businesses can open as of 4.00 and must close by 2.00 at the latest.Alcohol sales can start at 9.00 at the earliest and must stop at 1.00 at the latest.Buffets will be permitted again.Three quarters of the number of persons permitted in the serving licence or building plan may be present in the indoor premises of a food and beverage service business at one time.

As of 22 June 2020, the decree will be amended so that food and beverage service businesses can open as of 4.00 and must close by 2.00 at the latest.Alcohol sales can start at 9.00 at the earliest and must stop at 1.00 at the latest.Buffets will be permitted again.Three quarters of the number of persons permitted in the serving licence or building plan may be present in the indoor premises of a food and beverage service business at one time.

Measure_L3: Re-opening of medical and paramedical centers
Comment: The Government has decided to dismantle the recommendation to avoid visits to hospitals. The lifting of the restriction concerns persons receiving hospital treatment in both specialised and primary healthcare.
Finland has committed EUR 2 million to support Iraq’s response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Support tourism, sport and culture sectors
Comment: The Government supports the development of tourism in the regions by EUR 4 million. In addition, the Government will allocate EUR 0.5 million to a campaign to promote domestic tourism.

Measure_L2: Financial support as part as recovery measures
Measure_L4: Support to domestic travel and tourism
Comment: 100 Reasons to Travel in Finland campaign expanded to support domestic travel and tourism. The Government has allocated additional financing of EUR 500,000 to support domestic travel and tourism as part of the recovery measures related to the COVID-19 crisis. The financing will be used to implement a national domestic tourism campaign in connection with the ongoing 100 reasons to travel in Finland campaign by the Finnish Association of Tourism Organisations, Suoma ry.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Economic support to the maritime sector
Comment: As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, the operating conditions for Finnish cargo and passenger shipping companies have become considerably more difficult. The purpose of the grant is to promote the sufficiency of maritime transport capacity and the restoration of confidence in maritime transport and to help maintain the operational capacity of shipping companies.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Comment: Parliament has approved the Government’s proposals to extend the duration of the temporary amendments concerning lay-offs, co-operation procedures and the right of laid-off employees and entrepreneurs to unemployment security until the end of 2020.The amendments made to the Employment Contracts Act, the Seafarers’ Employment Contracts Act and the Act on Co-operation within Undertakings since 1 April 2020 will remain in force until the end of 2020.

Measure_L3: State aid, taxation and social security
Measure_L4: Government supports the obtention of unemployment benefits
Comment: Parliament has approved the Government’s proposals to extend the duration of the temporary amendments concerning lay-offs, co-operation procedures and the right of laid-off employees and entrepreneurs to unemployment security until the end of 2020.The amendments made to the Employment Contracts Act, the Seafarers’ Employment Contracts Act and the Act on Co-operation within Undertakings since 1 April 2020 will remain in force until the end of 2020.

Measure_L4: Lift border control with countries showing similar epidemiological situation
Comment: In its meeting, the Government agreed that as of 13 July, it would lift the internal border control and restrictions on traffic between Finland and countries where the incidence of COVID-19 is similar to that in countries where internal border control has already been lifted.

Measure_L4: Encourage transition to normal working conditions
Comment: In its meeting, the Government stated that the recommendation on extensive remote work would end on 1 August due to the improved epidemiological situation. The summer holiday season in July will allow for a flexible, step-by-step transition towards normal working conditions.

Government decided to reinstate internal border control for traffic between Finland and Austria, Slovenia and Switzerland. These countries have seen an increase in the number of COVID-19 infections since the previous assessment.

In line with the regulation issued by the Regional State Administrative Agencies, public events and public meetings with more than 500 attendees may be held in indoor and enclosed outdoor spaces, provided that they comply with the guidelines from the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare and the Ministry of Education and Culture on preventing COVID-19 infections.

The Ministry of Education and Culture and the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare have updated the instructions related to the coronavirus epidemic they issued to education providers and educational institutions in the spring. The most important thing is, also from now on, to prevent infections, ensure good hygiene, avoid unnecessary close contacts, and arrange teaching premises more spaciously than usual. By following these recommendations, the risk of infection and the spread of the coronavirus can be reduced.

Government decided to reinstate internal border control for traffic between Finland and the Netherlands and between Finland and Belgium. Restrictions on external border traffic will be reinstated for traffic from Andorra to Finland. The number of coronavirus cases in the Netherlands, Belgium and Andorra has taken an upward turn since the previous assessment.

Measure_L1: Case identification, contact tracing and related measures
Comment: To prevent the spread of the coronavirus, more measures will be targeted at travellers arriving in Finland from so-called high-risk countries. These include an official quarantine order or a requirement to take a coronavirus test.

Measure_L3: Conditional entry of travelers from high-risk areas
Measure_L4: Home quarantine or negative PCR test
Comment: To prevent the spread of the coronavirus, more measures will be targeted at travellers arriving in Finland from so-called high-risk countries. These include an official quarantine order or a requirement to take a coronavirus test.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Measure_L4: Promote the use of face masks
Comment: On Thursday 13 August, the Government adopted in its plenary session resolutions on recommendations for wearing face coverings and face masks and for remote work.

Measure_L2: Increase in medical supplies and equipment
Measure_L3: Ban on exportation of medical equipment and drugs
Comment: Restrictions on the sale of medicinal products containing paracetamol or dexamethasone to ensure their availability and sufficiency

Measure_L4: Global response to Covid-19 World Food Programme
Comment: By decision of Minister Skinnari, Finland will contribute EUR 3 million to a logistics operation of the World Food Programme (WFP) aiming to alleviate the effects of the COVID-19 crisis.

Measure_L4: With Iceland, Greece, Malta, Germany, Norway and Denmark
Comment: Internal border control will be reinstated for traffic between Finland and Iceland, Greece, Malta, Germany, Norway and Denmark.
Finland has decided to take part in the joint EU agreement to purchase coronavirus vaccines. Finland informed the European Commission of its decision on 21 August.

Measure_L4: With Japan, Ireland, Cyprus and San Marino
Comment: Based on the current epidemiological assessment, restrictions on entry into the country will be reinstated for traffic between Finland and the following countries: Iceland, Greece, Malta, Germany, Norway, Denmark, Ireland, Cyprus and San Marino. In addition, the restrictions will apply to Japanese residents on flights arriving in Finland from Japan.

Measure_L2: Educate and actively communicate with the public
Measure_L3: Promote use of a smartphone application against Corona
Comment: The Koronavilkku smartphone app has now been published to help break infection chains. You can now download Koronavilkku to your phone free of charge from the most popular app stores.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Economic support to the most affected workers and businesses
Comment: An appropriation of EUR 60 million is proposed in temporary compensation to help mitigate the effects of the epidemic.The compensation would be used to support the most economically disadvantaged people and families in society in situations where the restrictive measures imposed due to the COVID-19 epidemic have generated additional costs.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Support tourism, sport and culture sectors
Comment: A new variable appropriation of EUR 2 million is proposed for compensation related to the bankruptcy of tour operators. It would be used to compensate consumers for cancellations of travel packages due to the COVID-19 situation if they cannot be reimbursed from the guarantees provided by tour operators.

Measure_L3: Decrease time between test and result
Comment: The budget proposal for 2021 reserves a total of EUR 1.4 billion for coronavirus testing. EUR 355 million will be reserved for this in the autumn 2020 supplementary budget proposal. With this funding, it will be possible to make testing faster and more comprehensive than before.

The Government proposes that EUR 200 million be allocated for supporting municipalities and hospital districts. Municipalities and hospital district can use these funds to cover any direct costs arising from the coronavirus epidemic, excluding costs related to testing.

The Government proposes that EUR 200 million be allocated for supporting municipalities and hospital districts. Municipalities and hospital district can use these funds to cover any direct costs arising from the coronavirus epidemic, excluding costs related to testing.
The Government proposes a total of EUR 347 million in compensation to organisations, associations and foundations for securing their funding.

Measure_L4: Land border controls with Schengen countries
Comment: According to the Schengen Borders Code, internal border control between the Schengen countries should not, as a rule, be continued beyond a maximum period of six months. However, it is possible to make justified exceptions to this. In Finland, the six-month period will end on 18 September. The Government has decided that, in order to fight the second wave of the COVID-19 epidemic, Finland will continue to impose country-specific restrictions on entry at its internal borders from 19 September to 18 October 2020.

Measure_L4: With Estonia, Germany, Iceland, Norway, Slovakia, Sweden, Canada, Georgia, Tunisia
Comment: Restrictions on entry will be reintroduced for traffic between Finland and Estonia, Germany, Iceland, Norway, Slovakia and Sweden, as well as for residents of Canada, Georgia and Tunisia who are travelling from their home country to Finland.

Measure_L3: State aid, taxation and social security
Comment: Lower fees in early childhood education and care will increase employment and raise the participation rate in early childhood education and care.

New restrictions will be imposed on the opening and licensing hours of food and beverage service businesses in order to curb the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic. From (and including) Thursday 8 October, food and beverage service businesses may be open between 4.00 and 1.00. From 8 October, alcohol sales may begin no earlier than 9.00 and must end no later than 24.00.

New restrictions will be imposed on the opening and licensing hours of food and beverage service businesses in order to curb the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic. Measure_L4: Movements to and from the region of Uusimaa will be restricted until 19th April.
Comment: "the Government decided to restrict traffic between the Region of Uusimaa and other regions as of 27 March... After the entry into force of the movement restrictions, the residents of Uusimaa must stay in the Uusimaa region. Residents of other regions are not allowed to visit Uusimaa. However, everyone has the right to return to their home or place of residence. Recreational travel is not allowed."

Restrictions on movement to and from Uusimaa enter into force on 28 March 2020. On 27 March, the Government submitted to Parliament two decrees concerning the Uusimaa region on the entry into force and the application of the restrictions on movement laid down in the Emergency Powers Act. The restrictions concern movement to and from the Uusimaa region. The movement restrictions in the Uusimaa region will enter into force on 28 March and remain in force until 19 April 2020.

Measure_L4: Ban on travel outside municipality of residence except for work
Comment: Once the restrictions enter into force, the residents of Uusimaa must stay in the Uusimaa region. Residents of other regions are not allowed to visit Uusimaa.

Government decided to immediately lift the restrictions on movement in the region of Uusimaa. When the travel restrictions entered into force on 28 March, COVID-19 incidence in the region of Uusimaa was increasing significantly faster than in the rest of the country. While Uusimaa still has the highest number of COVID-19 cases, the gap with the rest of the country has narrowed.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Support tourism, sport and culture sectors
Comment: With its emergency aid program, the state government also supports artists and cultural workers who are affected by the effects of the corona pandemic. The state government today launched the cross-sector Corona Emergency Aid Program  for the country's economy to alleviate the massive impact of the Corona pandemic.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Comment: Agriculture Minister Peter Hauk has announced that he will be supporting the Baden-Württemberg farmers in the current corona crisis with a variety of measures. For example, direct financial aid from the state for commercial sub-businesses in agriculture and relief for the use of seasonal workers are possible. For example, the Ministry of Economic Affairs is offering agricultural holdings through the “Guideline for the support of the self-employed individuals, companies and members of the liberal professions damaged by the corona pandemic”, which are in an economic situation that threatens their very existence as a result of the corona pandemic or suffer massive liquidity shortages appropriate help for their commercial sub-companies, provided that the requirements of the aforementioned directive are met. The federal government has also expanded the regulations for the granting of small grants by the federal states. The Landwirtschaftliche Rentenbank also offers a program to secure liquidity.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Strengthen support for skills upgrade and in-house training
Comment: In order to support companies and trainees who are affected by the rise in short-time work due to the corona pandemic and the economic downturn, the Ministry of Economic Affairs is facilitating the promotion of integrated training for short-time companies.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Partial or total deferral of tax payments for businesses
Comment: Further tax relief for companies. There are additional tax breaks for companies affected by the spread of the corona virus. "We are constantly examining how we can provide targeted and unbureaucratic help," said Finance Minister Edith Sitzmann . In addition to interest-free deferrals and waivers for late payments, it is now also possible to reduce special advance payments for sales tax for 2020. This is a special payment for a long-term extension, with which the registration and payment of VAT is postponed by one month. So you pay a kind of discount to have to settle later.

Waste from quarantine households and doctor's surgeries must be securely packaged to protect third parties and disposed of in the residual waste bin. The Ministry of the Environment directs waste disposal advice to urban and rural districts during the Corona epidemic.

Measure_L3: Develop all-of-society and business continuity plans
Measure_L4: Support tourism, sport and culture sectors
Comment: The country does not abandon volunteering in the corona crisis. In order to support sports clubs in need, funds in the Solidarity Pact for Sports are used in a targeted manner. Popular sports clubs that carry out an economic activity can also fall under the rescue packages of the federal and state governments. The State Sports Association (LSV) and the Ministry of Culture, Youth and Sports are in constant contact to analyze the situation and to provide targeted support measures. In coordination with the LSV, funds will immediately be used in the current “Solidarpakt Sport” to support sports clubs in need. If this measure is not sufficient, they will work for a supplementary emergency fund.

Effective immediately, additional laboratory capacities for testing for the corona virus are available at the Chemical and Veterinary Research Office in Stuttgart. Food safety and animal health remain high.

The country and the municipalities are creating an aid network for families in the Corona crisis. The state pays emergency aid of 100 million euros for cities and municipalities. The daycare fees can thus be waived for the time of closure.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs has drawn up a guideline for cash desk workplaces that the responsible authorities and employers can use as a guide.

After the approval of the Federal Council and the signing of the law by the Federal President last Friday, the state of Baden-Württemberg published a catalog of fines based on the amendment to the Infection Protection Act. Citizens who do not comply with the state ordinance to contain the corona virus face severe fines.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs is planning to expand its tried and tested instrument for early-stage funding for start-up projects, “Start-up BW Pre-Seed” because of the Corona crisis, and to also support crisis-ridden start-ups at short notice with a repayable grant of 200,000 euros.

As Finance Minister, I am happy to support this with a tax exemption ”, explained Finance Minister Edith Sitzmann
